statement.p: Represent the vector \vec{1 2}, with respect to the basis B=\left\{\vec{1 1},\vec{-1 1}\right\} of \R^2.
Represent the vector with respect to each of the two bases. v=\vec{3 -1} \quad B_1=\left\{\vec{1 -1}, \vec{1 1}\right\}, B_2=\left\{\vec{1 2}, \vec{1 3}\right\}

answer.p: Solving \vec{3 -1}=\vec{1 -1}\cdot c_1 + \vec{1 1}\cdot c_2 gives c_1=2 and c_2=1. Similarly, solving \vec{3 -1}=\vec{1 2}\cdot c_1 + \vec{1 3}\cdot c_2 gives c_1=10, c_2=-7.

statement.p:
Consider the vector
v_1 = \vec{1 1 1 1} \qquad v_2 = \vec{1 -1 1 -1} \qquad v_3 = \vec{2 0 -2 0} \qquad v_4 = \vec{4 0 0 0}
and the subspace W = \Span{v_1, v_2, v_3, v_4}.
Find a linear dependence relation among v1, v2, v3, v4.
What is the dimension of W ?
Which subsets of {v1, v2, v3, v4} form a basis for W?
Choose a basis \cB for W from (c), and find the \c B-coordinates of the vector w=\vec{0 0 4 0}.
[Hint: it is helpful, but not necessary, to use the fact that {v_1, v_2, v_3} is orthogonal.]

answer.p:
We know that {v_1, v_2, v_3} is linearly independent, because it is an orthogonal set. Hence v_4 must be a linear combination of v_1, v_2, v_3, i.e., v_4 is in \Span{v_1, v_2, v_3}. We can compute the coordinates using dot products:
v_4 = \frac{v_4 \cdot v_1}{v_1 \cdot v_1}v_1 + \frac{v_4 \cdot v_2}{v_2 \cdot v_2}v_2 + \frac{v_4 \cdot v_3}{v_3 \cdot v_3}v_3 = v_1 + v_2 + v_3
. Hence v_1 + v_2 + v_3 - v_4 =0 is a linear dependence relation.
We know that {v_1, v_2, v_3} is linearly independent, and it spans W because v_4 is in \Span{v_1, v_2, v_3}. Thus \dim(W)=3.
Any set of three vectors from {v_1, v_2, v_3, v_4} spans W, because the fourth is a linear combination of the other three (from v_1 + v_2 + v_3 - v_4 = 0). Hence any three vectors in {v_1, v_2, v_3, v_4} is a basis for W.
We choose the basis \cB = {v_1, v_2, v_3}. Then
[w]_{\cB} = \left(\frac{w \cdot v_2}{v_1 \cdot v_1}, \frac{w \cdot v_2}{v_2 \cdot v_2}, \frac{w \cdot v_3}{v_3 \cdot v_3}\right) = \left(1, 1, -1\right) .
Alternatively, you can ignore the fact that {v_1, v_2, v_3} is orthogonal and use row reduction in (a), (b), and (d), but this requires more work.

statement.p: Let \cB_1 = \{\vec{2 3}, \vec{1 -1}\} and \cB_2=\{\vec{2 1}, \vec{5 3}\} be two bases of \R^2. Find the change of basis matrix \underset{\cB_2 \leftarrow \cB_1}{P}. (Recall that for each x \text{ in } \R^2, \underset{\cB_2 \leftarrow \cB_1}{P} maps [x]_{\cB_1} to [x]_{\cB_2}).
